content.text: Determine the speed of the car at time \(= 2.0s.\)
speed of the car = .........
Calculate the distance travelled by the car between time \(= 0\) and time \(= 4.0s.\)
distance travelled = .........
Calculate the deceleration of the car between time \(= 0.5s\) and time \(= 4.0s.\)
deceleration = .........
[Total: 7]
A car travels at a speed of \(20 \text{m/s}\). The driver applies the brakes when he sees a red traffic light
Fig. 1.1 shows the speed–time graph for the car
Show that the momentum of the space vehicle is approximately \(6.55 \times 10^6 \text{kg} \text{m/s}\)
The capsule ejects the nose cone, as shown in Fig. 2.2
Determine the velocity \(v\) of the capsule after the nose cone is ejected. Give your answer to 3 significant figures
A different space capsule returns to Earth
Fig. 2.3 shows this capsule just before it lands in the sea
The capsule travels at terminal velocity
The upward vertical force acting on the capsule is \(120 \text{kN}\)
Calculate the mass of the capsule
mass of the capsule = .........
[Total: 6]
Fig. 2.1 shows a space vehicle which consists of a capsule and a nose cone
The space vehicle is moving at a velocity of \(7800 \text{m/s}\). The mass of the space vehicle is \(840 \text{kg}\)
The archer pulls back on the bow string, doing a total of 110J of work. Her hand moves a distance of \(0.45m\) . The bow is bent and stores energy
Show that the average force applied by the archer in pulling the string back is approximately 240N
Calculate the initial speed \(v\) of the arrow
initial speed $v =$ .........
Explain why the speed of the arrow as it hits the target is less than the value in (b)(i)
The archer releases the bow string. All the energy in (a) is transferred to the arrow
The arrow moves off at an initial speed \(v\) . The mass of the arrow is \(0.030 \text{kg}\)
Fig. 3.1 shows an archer aiming an arrow at a target
Explain how thermal energy is conducted through the copper base
Define, in words, specific heat capacity

A student heats a metal object to \(100^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) . The student places the metal object in an insulated cup containing water at \(22^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) . The final temperature of the water and the metal object is \(31^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
The specific heat capacity of water is \(4.2 \text{J} / (\text{g} \circ \text{C})\)
The mass of the water in the insulated cup is \(50 \text{g}\)
The mass of the metal object is \(54 \text{g}\)
Calculate the specific heat capacity of the metal
specific heat capacity = .........
[Total: 8]
Fig. 4.1 shows a pan with a copper base on a hotplate. The hotplate heats the pan and the water
Define, in words, refractive index for a ray of light travelling from air to water
On Fig. 5.1, draw the path of rays P and Q at the water–air boundary
The angle of incidence for ray R is \(49^{\circ}\)
Calculate the refractive index of the water
refractive index = .........
Explain why ray S is totally internally reflected at the water surface
[Total: 7]
Fig. 5.1 shows four rays of red light, P, Q, R and S, coming from a spotlight in a swimming pool
Define the term ultrasound
Describe what is meant by a longitudinal wave
Describe how ultrasound is used to locate an object below the surface of the sea
You may draw a labelled diagram as part of your answer
State one other use of ultrasound
[Total: 6]
Ultrasound is used to locate objects below the surface of the sea
Ultrasound is an example of a longitudinal wave

current = .........

resistance = .........

Calculate the charge that flows

Calculate the charge that flows

There is an alternating current in the primary coil
Describe how an alternating current is produced in the secondary coil
A step-up transformer has a turns ratio of 1:20. The voltage across the primary coil is 12V
Calculate the voltage across the secondary coil
voltage across secondary coil = .........
Fig. 9.1 shows a transformer
The power lost in a cable is \(1.25 \times 10^{-3} \text{W}\). The resistance of the cable is \(0.050 \Omega\)
Calculate the current in the cable
State two advantages of high-voltage transmission
Define a light-year in words
It takes light 490 s to travel from the Sun to the Earth
Calculate the distance from the Sun to the Earth
distance = .........
Fig. 10.1 is a scatter graph showing how the speed of galaxies moving away from the Earth varies with their distances from the Earth
distance of galaxy from Earth/ \(10^{20}km\)
A scientist draws a best-fit line on the scatter graph
Use this best-fit line to determine a value for the Hubble constant
The speed of a receding galaxy can be estimated using redshift
Describe what is meant by redshift
[Total: 8]
Define the half-life of a radioactive source
Complete the nuclear equation for the decay
State the change that occurs in the nucleus during the decay
A protactinium (Pa) nucleus decays into a uranium (U) nucleus by the emission of a beta particle (β-particle)
A different element decays by the emission of an alpha particle (α-particle)
Give two reasons why \(\alpha\) -particles are more strongly ionising than \(\beta\) -particles
